reviewText: Every episode in this box set is a classic.  All the best schemes Cartman comes up with to get ten million dollars are in this set:  The toothfairy scheme, the boyband, under-age evangelism, all the good stuff.  The comentary-minis, as Parker and Stone call them, are perfect for those who like hearing commentary, but don't like when it goes on for the whole program.  They talk for just the first few minutes of each episode, and then stop so that you can enjoy the comedy.  They also split the episodes into chapters of their own so that you can more easily find your favorite part, or skip through the opening theme so you don't get tired of it. Oh, one more thing...Timmy rules!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone deliver a great season of hilarious satire and gross-out comedy.  It's sometimes amazing that they can skewer so many targets in roughly 25 minutes.  Once a "South Park" episode gets started, you have no idea where it's going.  It's difficult to isolate stand-out episodes, but I'd probably have to select the "Do the Handicapped Go to Hell?/Probably" two-parter (in which Satan agonizes over whether to resume his love affair with Saddam Hussein), "The Wacky Molestation Adventure" (the adults of South Park are taken away over accusations of child molestation, leaving the children to revert to savagery), and "Cartman Joins NAMBLA" (self-explanatory).  Stone and Parker also perform a valuable service for book lovers everywhere by presenting a faithful abridgment of Dickens's "Great Expectatrions," complete with evil robotic monkeys and immortality devices.
summary: Made me spit out my drink a few times
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great box set, and if you are a fan of the show, you must own this season. With season 4 you get Timmy, Ms. Choksondik and you get to meet Mr. Hanky's family! South Park has evolved by Season 4, and there is more to these episodes than just the shock-humor South Park became known for. You get some classic episodes on this season, like when the boys start 4th grade, and Ike goes to Kindergarten. You get the show where Cartman's Dawson's Creek Trapper Keeper takes over the world. I personally love the show where Cartman forms a boy band called "Fingerbang" and has Timmy shoot thier music video.  "Cartman Joins NAMBLA" is worth the price of this set alone, and the two parter "Do the Handicapped Go to Hell" & "Probably" is just a riot. Sure, you sometimes feel a little guilty when laughing at Timmy when his time-machine wheelchair turns into a rolling bomb, or when Cartman sneaks junk food into a fat-camp he's been forced to go to, but that is why South Park is so great. We get to laugh at everything we are told not to laugh at. The writing this season is crisper, and each story packs so much into its 22 minutes you will find yourself going back for 2nd viewings because you miss so much the first time. If you haven't picked this up yet, you don't know what you are missing.
summary: Almost Every Episode is Worth 5 Stars!!

reviewText: I used to really hate this show, because I didn't see it for what it was. I thought it was sophomoric and gross for the sake of being gross.Well, that's true, the show likes to push limits of decency, but the characters are so crude and cartoonish that you can disassociate what they are doing to each other with reality fairly easily. I realize what I am watching desensitizes me, but I also know I am going to get a unique perspective on a real-world topic. A story crafted from the headlines into the most atrociously outrageous fable, dramatically arcing from a simple beginning to a convoluted ending which is finally condensed into a "you know, I learned something today..." monologue.I don't know how they do it, but Trey and Matt are able to give a very moral perspective in an incredibly immoral way.
summary: More Fun With the Kids of South Park
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have never been a big fan of South Park, but really got into it when the season sets were released. I have seen the first three seasons, and while they are great, it only gets better in this season. The raunch and vulgarity you would expect from the show is even sharper in season 4, and you will find even more satire within the episodes. Ranging from issues such as race, government and boy bands, the creators of South Park spare no one. Many of my favorite episodes are contained in this set, a few being Cartman's Silly Hate Crime, Fat Camp, and Trapper Keeper. In Hate Crime, Cartman goes to prison for committing a crime against another race. Clearly pokes fun at the hate crime laws in this country with the message that crime is crime and should be punished accordingly. Many of the episode contain this kind of criticism and that is what makes the show much more than vulgar trash like some people think. Those are only 3 of my favorites though, and there are other classic episodes, NAMBLA definately being one. The only episode I don't care too much for is Pip, as it contains none of the South Park regulars. It isn't a horrible episode though. But as you can tell, the best episodes in my opinion are the Cartman-centric ones, as another reviewer put it.The DVD package we get is okay, but I know there are many more extras we could have and should have gotten. Essentially there are only the mini-commentaries on some episodes, but other than 17 great episodes there is nothing else really exciting in this whole set. This may disappoint some fans of the show, but I am just happy to own the complete season 4 that I can watch whenever I feel like doing so. I think if these sets were $10-$15 cheaper it would be a fair price, but I do feel like the $49.99 SRP is too high. Usually I would care, but this is South Park and this is a show worthy of being overpriced if there is any. So to wrap it up, I recommend saving your $$$ and buying this set, the best season released to dvd so far. 17 classic episodes are here that every South Park fan should own.
summary: My favorite season yet on dvd.

reviewerName: Mark Eremite "This Is A Display Model Only"
reviewText: After the blow-out success of their movie, creators Stone and Parker realized just how much they could get away with in their show (there are some funny stories about that in the mini-commentaries to be found on these discs).  They used this new-found power not just to reach new heights of depravity, but also to more effectively utilize the show as their own personal soapbox.  A tactic like this would cripple shows of less caliber; it is what gave South Park its new legs.Proving themselves capable of taking on any subject (and rivaling even some news programs with their blink-of-an-eye topicality), season four finds the kids waxing philosophic on hate crimes (Cartman's Silly Hate Crime 2000), the Elian Gonzales controversy (Quintuplets 2000), holistic medicine (Cherokee Hair Tampons), the Confederate flag (Chef Goes Nanners), the presidential election (Trapper Keeper), and, of course, religion, in the two-parter "Do the Handicapped Go to Hell?" & "Probably," which could be viewed as a quasi-sequel to the movie.Most notably, this season introduces us to Timmy, a character that Comedy Central initially (and understandably) balked at.  Thank God they let this vocabulary-challenged child on the air; who would've guessed that this unlikely staple to the show would prove to be much much more than a one-joke wonder.The boys behind the screen also churned out some of their most famous episodes this year.  Kenny gets grosser than ever (and Cartman slims down, maybe) in "Fat Camp."  South Park goes rogue when the parents all leave town in "The Wacky Molestation Adventure."  We are treated to a disturbing (and absolutely hilarious) look into the gory depths of Cartman's brain in "Helen Keller! The Musical."  Mr. Hanky returns in "A Very Crappy Christmas."  And, in arguably one of the shows best episodes ever (if not the most memorable), Cartman -- seeking more "mature" friends -- joins NAMBLA.The show skids a few times in this season.  Their recreation of Dickens' "Great Expectations" is amusing, but only gets laugh-worthy when the show strays from the script (Genesis machine! Robot monkeys!).  Even on the mini-commentary (these guys aren't just a treat to listen to, they also give the inside scoop on a lot of things you'd want to know anyway), the creators admit "Chef Goes Nanners" has their most "bummer" ending.  And although "4th Grade" is responsible for introducing us to Ms. Choksondik (and also for finally outing Mr. Garrison), it seems like one of the weakest episodes in this season.But, then again, in a season starring Cheech and Chong, where we're treated to a reality-warping Kyle and Cartman as the tooth fairy, where a handicapped child gets a handicapped pet, and where the kids form a boy band with an unlikely name, the competition is notably fierce.  Another great season for a stand-out show.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Fourth season was good!  The episodes I like were: Cartman's Silly Hate Crime 2000, Timmy 2000, Cartman Joins Nambla, Do the Handicapped go to Hell?, Probably, The wacky molestation adventure and a very crappy Christmas.Overall it's still a worthy addition.The Tooth Fairy Tats 2000:  Cartman makes two dollars from the tooth fairy and comes up with a scheme to make money for a Sega Dreamcast.  He and the boys run up against organized crime and Ms. Carman gets concerned about the loss of teeth and has run out of money.Cartman's Silly Hate Crime 2000:  Cartman nails Token in the head with a rock and the government steps in an arrests him for a hate crime.  He goes to jail and soon acts as a mule.  The boys need him for a sled race against the girls.  They set out to get him free.Timmy 2000:  There is a new student named Timmy.  He disrupts class and is sent to the principle.  Mr. Mackey has him tested for ADD and the fact his can only say Timmy says he is (never mind the fact he is retarded).  He gets to skip homework so the rest of the kids decide they have the same thing.  They all get prescribed Ritalin.  Soon the parents are taking it too.  Chef decides he has to save the day because the everybody is going to see a Phil Collins concert.  A parallel story involves Timmy joining the Rock Band Timmy and the Lords of the Underworld.  Skylar is back and has issues with the new direction of the bandQuintuplets 2000:  The boys are dragged to Circus Chaville.  They almost pass out when they see 9-year-old contorting quintuplets from Romania.  While trying to set up their own circus, Kenny sets off on a journey to become a great singer and the quints and their grandmother decide to seek asylum.  They end up in Stan's house.  Now the plans for the circus are complete.  But alas, the Romanian government protests ala Elian Gonzalez and we have Janet Reno leading an assault to recover the quints.  At the same time Kenny sings his way to Romania and is asked to stay because of his beautiful voice.Cartman Joins NAMBLA:  Cartman feels he has matured more then his friends and decides he needs to find more mature friends.  Where to search?  The Internet of course! He makes contacts and each time he meets one, the FBI arrest them.  A few more tries and he learns of an organization called NAMBLA and joins it.  He also decides to become the poster child for it!  Dr. Mephesto is also a member of NAMBLA!Cherokee Hair Tampons:  Kyle has a failing Kidney!  Stan's mother suggests alternative medicine and they go meet Miss Information!  She introduces them to Native Americans Cheech and Chong!  Stan desperate to save his friend realizes it's not going to work and returns to western medicine for advice.  He needs a transplant and the only one with the same blood type?  CARTMAN!Chef Goes Nanners:  The flag of South Park is declared racist by Chef.  This causes a great debate at school.  Stan and Kyle defend the flag as historic while Wendy and Cartman declare it racist.  Wendy starts having dreams about Cartman and Chef converts to Islam and changes his name.  Look to Stan's face as Wendy decides to deal with her problemSomething You Can Do With Your Finger: Cartman decides to form a boy band called FingerBang to make 10 million dollars.  Stan's father is against it and confesses his past as a former member of a boy band.  A major problem happens.  There are 4 members and everybody knows you have to have 5.Do the Handicapped go to Hell?:  Part one.  Father Maxi's gives a sermon about Hell and all kids start going to Sunday school to avoid Hell.  Kyle even decides to play it safe.  Problems happen after concern for Timmy who can't confess his Sins since he can only say Timmy!  Cartman decides to become a preacher in order to save the children.  A side story involves Satan and his new boyfriend Chris.  Saddam returns and causes problems as he tries to win Satan back.Probably:  Part two.  Cartman and the children start building a church while Satan spends the night with Saddam.  Satan decides to talk to God about his relationship problems while Saddam keeps killing Chris.Fourth Grade:  The boys move on to the 4th grade and are filled with remorse.  They decide they have to time travel back and live happily in the 3rd grade again.  The new teacher Ms. Choksondik can't handle the class and seeks out Mr. Garrison who is now living in cave on top of a mountain.  Only he can know what to do and yet he has to decide if he is gay or not.Trapper Keeper:  Cartman has a new trapper keeper and brags about it to no end.  A stranger appears on the bus and he tells a tale of doom where the trapper keeper must be destroyed.  A side story involves Mr. Garrison teaching the kindergarten class.  They have an election for class president and soon find themselves embroiled in a Florida like election problemHelen Keller! The Musical:  The 4th grade is doing a play on the miracle worker.  They learn that the kindergarten class has a superior play.  Cartman is the stage director and can't be out done.  Timmy plays Helen Keller and gets a new friend gobbles.Pip:  In a version of Great Expectations narrated by an Englishman (Malcom McDowell), Pip gets a job at Haversham Estate and meets his love Estella who seems to only insult him.  Pip becomes a gentleman and learns that Miss Haversham seeks to break his heart.  Her plan involves robot monkeys and the geneses device.Fat Camp:  Ms. Choksondik has a class on dissecting Manatees.  The children pay Kenny to eat some spleen.  He soon gets a career eating anything and doing crazy things.  Mrs. Cartman holds an intervention and sends Cartman to a fat camp.  He returns 40 pounds lighter.The Wacky Molestation Adventure:  Cartman gets 4 tickets to the "Raging Pussies" and Kyle can't go.  He argues with his parents and they say he can go if Cuba changes to a democracy.  Kyle writes Castro and convinces him to change.  Kyle still can't go.  Cartman suggests turning in his parents for molestation.  Soon all kids do the same.  South Park soon descends in to anarchy where two rival camps set up.  The Kindergartners with Stan and Kyle as leaders  vs. the older kids with Cartman as the leader.  A couple wanders into town and needs a cell phone and is sent on a couple quests to win the use of it.A Very Crappy Christmas:  Mr. Hankey doesn't appear.  Christmas spirit is gone and people aren't shopping anymore.  The Boys go looking for him and find he has a family which takes all his time now.  In order to save Christmas the boys decide to make a movie to short film to restore the Christmas spirit.  The movie they make; "The Spirit of Christmas"There are commentaries but I haven't listened to them yet.

reviewText: There are two kinds of people out there: Southpark fans, and non-Southpark fans. Southpark fans, in general, are averagely bright, 18-40 year olds who can stay on pace with the quick, sometimes genius Southpark writing. Of the latter group, the non-fans, they can be divided into two subcategories: ignorant people and angry people. The ignorant are just that; they may just be too busy, might be passing on the chance of watching because "it's just a cartoon" or maybe saw one of the earlier episodes and got bored. To these people, I say try again. Enjoy the 21 minute episodes while you still can! Buy this DVD and watch every episode... you don't even have to listen to the commentary by Matt and Trey. Only the dorky Southpark fans do that. To address the angry people, well, screw you guys anyways. I don't expect you to enjoy something like Southpark anyways.

reviewText: The mere fact that a movie or book is disturbing is neither good nor bad; in fact, if the only thing it has going for it is shock value, eventually the reader or viewer will get numb and go elsewhere for entertainment.  The makers of South Park realize this; all the shocking material it presents would be valueless if it weren't also well-written, but it is, so South Park is worth watching.As in the third season, the fourth season of South Park is not only funny, but creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone continue to not rest on their laurels.  Instead they explore new places and have the characters slowly develop.  This is most obvious in mid-season when Kenny, Stan, Kyle and Eric move on the fourth grade and get a new teacher.  Old teacher Mr. Garrison has retreated to the woods, unable to come to terms with his sexual orientation; only there, in a scene out of The Empire Strikes Back, will he finally become a new man.This season has all sorts of great stuff.  We get a sequel of sorts to the movie as Sadaam Hussein returns to wreak havoc in Hell.  Satan has moved on, but the attraction is still there; I really enjoyed how this one was resolved.  We are also introduced to Timmy, who we learn in the mini-commentaries was someone who Comedy Central was very wary about, at least until he became super-popular.  In other episodes, Cartman joins NAMBLA, Kenny becomes famous doing horrific stunts and, of course, Mr. Hanky returns to resurrect the true spirit of Christmas.  In addition, we get a very off-beat episode that is a version of Great Expectations featuring Pip (and robot monkeys).Every episode is fun, as are the mini-commentaries.  Admittedly, this show is not for everyone, but if you have watched it on TV and have found it funny, this is a set well worth getting.
summary: The Season in which Kenny died

reviewText: so said Rev. Cartman.  This fourth season set has made me a believer again!  I was a fan of South Park's earlier stuff but was very disappointed with the third season.  There were only two or three episodes on each disc that I liked and a lot of silly, annoying shows like Jakovasaurs and Sexual Harassment.  I decided to give the fourth season a chance, and boy what a difference a season makes!  Almost every episode here is awesome.  The only ones that is are a little weak are Pip (unless we really like the character Pip), A Very Crappy Christmas (unless you really like Mr. Hanky), and Trapper Keeper (though it does have a cool take-off of 2001 Space Odyssey).  I don't want to waste space gushing about each episode, but here are a few of my favorites:"Cartman's Silly Hate Crime 2000": Cartman is thrown in juvenile hall.  Tears actually came to my eyes when Cartman "presented" a "concealed" Tic-Tac-Throw game to his cellmate."Cartman Joins NAMBLA": One of my all-time favorite South Park episodes.  It is perhaps the most twisted Parker and Stone have made.  If you know that NAMBLA stands for the North American Man-Boy Love Association, you can probably imagine why."Chef Goes Nanners": Chef complains about the town flag he perceives as racist."Do the Handicapped Go to Hell?/Probably": These episodes are hilarious.  Cartman becomes a religious evangelist; meanwhile, Satan has to choose between sexual desire (uh hum, Saddam Hussein) and stability (his new wussy boyfriend Chris).In addition, this set also introduces Timmy and Miss Choksondik to the South Park family.  For those who like a lot of extras, you will probably be disappointed.  It just has previews for other Comedy Central DVDs and short, rather pointless commentaries by Parker and Stone.  If you are just wanting the episodes; though, this set has excellent stuff!  I am now waiting with greater anticipation for the fifth season of South Park to be released than I am for the fifth season of the Simpsons.
summary: "god b*tch-slapped him right to the fiery depths of hell"--
Title: N/A

reviewText: While the fourth season of South Park doesn't live up to the breakthrough brilliant hilarity of the previous seasons or the feature film that came before it, the fourth season is important nontheless.  The gang (Stan, Kyle, Cartman, and Kenny) move up to the fourth grade, and a new character is introduced that most fans of the series came to love: the wheelchair bound Timmy who is only capable of saying his name.  The boys also form their own boy band, and the truth about Mr. Garrison is finally revealed once and for all.  Still totally offensive and irreverant, the fourth season of South Park pulls no punches and still comes up a winner just as it as during it's entire series run.  Series creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker offer up another "mini-commentary" on the episodes, which is worth the price of admission here alone.

reviewText: I became an avid fan of South Park about a year ago, and have seen MANY episodes since.  Of all those episodes, most of my favorites are on this DVD set.  From my favorite episode, where Cartman's trapper keeper attempts to take over the world, to 'Cartman joins Nambla', Terry Parker and Matt Stone hit the mark with every episode durring their fourth season.  Introducing Timmy, Ms. Chokesondick (not sure how to spell that right), and several other characters, Parker and Stone deal with complex issues such as disability, hate crimes, and boy bands with extreme profesionalism and a great eye for satire.For anyone open minded, South Park can give you a new perspective on controversial issues.  Many people may be turned off by the sometimes gratuitous swearing that the children partake in, and the 'potty humor' used in many of the episodes, however, those who can make it past those are sure to enjoy the silly stories and somewhat inteligent humor that South Park throws at you in torrents.
summary: The Best Season of South Park
Title: N/A

reviewText: By season 4 of South Park some of the jokes were getting a little old, and it seemed like maybe Matt and Trey were running out of steam slightly, but still they managed to make every episode funny.  There's not a single bad episode in this entire season, though the episode "Pip" is sometimes under appreciated.The best episodes from this season include "Timmy 2000," which marked the introduction of the character Timmy.  At this point in the show he was a much funnier and more likeable character.  In later episodes where it seems like he actually understands what's happening around him I think they ruined the character, but in this episode he is absolutely great and completely oblivious.The two-parter follow-up to the South Park movie: "Do The Handicapped Go To Hell?" and "Probably" is positively gut-busting in its examination of the continuing homosexual drama between Satan, Sadam Hussein, and a new character: "the other man" named Chris.  These episodes are also one of the show's best critiques of the absurdities of Catholocism and religion in general, and reveals that Mormonism, in the South Park world, is the one true faith.To round out the season's best we have "Trapper Keeper," which was packed full of more pop-culture and current events references than probably any other episode up to that point, and "Chef Goes Nanners," which contains a very relevant (and positive) message on racism vs cultural heritage.
summary: Definitely not the best season, but still very strong

reviewText: After I completed watching the third season of "South Park" a few months ago, I concluded (and wrote on this site) that I considered it to be arguably the best season of any show in TV history.  Well, having watched season four in its entirety, I've been forced to revise my opinion.  This season is even better than its predecessor: sharper, funnier, more consistent, and more astute.  More importantly, while some sociopolitical commentary had found its way into previous seasons, it was here that Trey Parker and Matt Stone really launched their concerted assault on the conventional "wisdom" of our time, a campaign that has continued to this day.Now, one certainly shouldn't conclude that season four tones down South Park's legendary offensiveness, as there's still plenty of profanity and gross-out humor to be found here.  That said, "South Park" also emerged around this time as a reliable source of witty political commentary.  I recently read a column on the political website lewrockwell.com that outed Trey Parker as a card-carrying libertarian, and the emerging class of politically incorrect young people known as "South Park Republicans" has been well documented, perhaps most notably in the article "We're Not Losing the Culture War Anymore."  Could "South Park" be the public face of a resurgence of truth and common sense in the national debate?  Just maybe.  Indeed, while Trey and Matt hardly champion traditional conservative values on their show, much of this season is devoted to exposing the fallacies of the modern-day scourge known as liberalism and the bitter, resentful little trolls who subscribe to it.Sometimes, Trey and Matt will just come right out with their opposition to the latest left-wing nonsense, such as the devastatingly accurate description of hate-crime laws as a "savage hyprocrisy" in "Cartman's Silly Hate Crime 2000."  Similarly, in "Cartman Joins NAMBLA," the membership of the North American Man-Boy Love Association is portrayed as exactly what it is: a bunch of perverts who like to have sex with little boys.  "Cherokee Hair Tampon," which sees guest appearances from Cheech Marin and the outrageously incarcerated Tommy Chong, is an hilarious sendup of the baby boomer generation's sorry obsession with "natural" medicine where the kids' parents will swallow any PC tripe from a couple of "Native Americans" before the two admit that they're actually Mexicans.At other times, though, the show's message is a tad more subtle, although "subtle" is of course a relative term when it comes to this show.  "Chef Goes Nanners," based on the South Carolina Confederate Flag controversy, is a surprisingly insightful look at this country's weird racial divide.  "The Wacky Molestation Adventure," while one of the season's weirder episodes, is spot-on in its parody of the child-abuse hysteria that sends parents to prison on the thinnest suspicion of (as Cartman puts it) "molestering" their children (and if you don't think this happens, read Thomas Sowell's "The Vision of the Anointed").  And then there's "Quintuplets 2000," which makes some valid points about the whole Elian Gonzalez controversy while also presenting us with the unforgettable image of Janet Reno in an Easter Bunny suit.Oh, and did I mention that season four introduced us to Timmy, a wheelchair-bound monument to political incorrectness and one of TV history's most memorable characters (although I still prefer Tweek)?  His coming out episode, "Timmy 2000," makes fun of more than you might think possible in 22 minutes, including but not limited to Phil Collins, MTV, the ADD cult, and smarmy "advocates" for the handicapped who want to protect them from the outside world.  It also includes Timmy taking the role of lead singer for a metal band, a collaboration that leads to perhaps the single funniest song of all time.  Just imagine a kid who can only say his own name and grunt unintelligibly behind the mic at a rock concert and you'll have an idea of what I mean.Among the other highlights: the return of Saddam Hussein and Satan in the two-parter "Do the Handicapped Go to Hell?" and "Probably;" the simultaneous sci-fi parody and election commentary of "Trapper Keeper;" the outrageously offensive mockery of boy groups in "Something You Can Do with Your Finger;" and the introduction of the new teacher Ms. Choksondik in "Fourth Grade."  If you have the previous seasons but not this one, get it right away; the best is yet to come.  And if you don't have any seasons on DVD yet, repent your sins and get the four-pack.  You won't regret it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love satire. I grew up in the '50s and '60s, when radio and TV satire was virtually non-existant. Stan Freberg's CBS-radio show lasted all of 15 unsponsored weeks. "Rocky & Bullwinkle" ran five years. And that was about it. (The insipid "That Was the Week that Was" hardly counts.) This was the era when Lenny Bruce was arrested for using dirty language in front of an audience that had willingly paid money to see his performance.One might argue that the quantity and quality of satire is directly proportional to how courrupt society is -- or at least, how aware people are aware of the corruption. By that reasoning, we are living in extremely corrupt times.The last decade has seen the best TV satire ever -- "The Simpsons," "Beavis and Butthead," "King of the Hill," "South Park," and "The Daily Show." Most of it's animated -- you can get away with stuff in cartoons you can never get away with live."South Park" gets away with _everything_ (including coprophagy and eating one's parents, who've been served up as a bowl of chile -- see Greek mythology; it's there, too -- the cannibalism, not the chile), short of graphic sex. There has never been a more rude, in-your-face TV show. And little of it is gratuitous.Parker and Trey's principal targets are artistic and social trendiness, hypocrisy, political correctness, the failure of adults to listen to their children, and organized religion. (Not Christianity -- organized religion.) They're consistently on-target. No matter how outrageous the humor, they treat the material in a basically honest fashion, refusing (mostly) to take cheap shots. (When the world is as effed-up as it is, you don't _need_ to take pot shots.)This is seen best in one of the most-outrageous episodes, "Cartman Joins NAMBLA." The paederasts are portrayed in a not-unsympathetic manner (they're not slavering monsters), and at the end, one of them is allowed a sincere speech -- delivered without archess or irony -- defending their point of view ("We mean no harm. This is the way we are," etc). Then Stanley pipes up. "You have sex with children. You just don't get it, do you?"The politics of "South Park" are ambiguous. Trey and Parker could be Liberals with common sense, or Log Cabin Republicans. ("South Park" is consistently pro-gay, though in a subtle way.) Regardless, they have no hesitation attacking anything they think stupid or meretricious. (Look it up.) Which is almost everything.Simply for its uncompromising, no-holds-barred, take-no-prisoners attitude, I vote "South Park" as the best comedy that has yet appeared on American TV. Indeed, it is arguably the best "entertainment" program that has _ever_ been on TV. It's a shame Jonathan Swift didn't live to see it.
Title: N/A
